docs.lead_paragraph: The U.S. Supreme Court dealt unions a setback Monday by ruling that state-paid, in-home care workers in Illinois cannot be compelled to pay union dues, but stopped short of blocking organized labor from collecting such fees from other public employees.

headline.main: U.S. Top Court Lets Some Public Employees Avoid Union Dues
headline.print_headline: U.S. Top Court Lets Some Public Employees Avoid Union Dues

headline.main: Highlights from the Supreme Court's Decision in Hobby Lobby Case

docs.abstract: The decision opened the door to challenges from other corporations to many laws that may be said to violate their religious liberty.
docs.snippet: The decision opened the door to challenges from other corporations to many laws that may be said to violate their religious liberty.

headline.main: What's News in Washington: Supreme Court Ends Its Term

docs.abstract: A holiday-shortened week is set for a busy start, with the Supreme Court set to end its term Monday with a ruling on whether for-profit corporations can decline to provide insurance coverage for contraception on religious grounds.
docs.snippet: A holiday-shortened week is set for a busy start, with the Supreme Court set to end its term Monday with a ruling on whether for-profit corporations can decline to provide insurance coverage for contraception on religious grounds.

docs.lead_paragraph: The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday ruled that in-home care workers in Illinois who are paid by the state are not similar enough to government employees to be compelled to pay union dues.

headline.main: U.S. Top Court Rules Against Public Unions in In-Home Care Workers Case
headline.print_headline: U.S. Top Court Rules Against Public Unions in In-Home Care Workers Case

docs.snippet: The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday ruled that in-home care workers in Illinois who are paid by the state are not similar enough to government employees to be compelled to pay union dues.

headline.main: When a 20-Year Employee Becomes a Problem

docs.abstract: In the last post of a five-part series, a business owner talks about how he wrestled with a difficult decision — whether to fire an employee who had been extremely productive.
docs.snippet: In the last post of a five-part series, a business owner talks about how he wrestled with a difficult decision — whether to fire an employee who had been extremely productive.

docs.lead_paragraph: A boom has helped produce fortunes for some in Texas, but poverty endures in shantytowns without basic services like water and sewers.

headline.main: Boom Meets Bust in Texas: Atop Sea of Oil, Poverty Digs In
headline.print_headline: Boom Meets Bust in Texas: Atop Sea of Oil, Poverty Digs In

docs.abstract: Oil boom in Texas has done little to improve lives of poverty-stricken residents who live in shadow of natural gas processing plants and elsewhere; town of Gardendale, Tex, one of many decrepit shantytowns that have come to be known as colonias, lacks even most basic services like clean water, sewers and police; area presents searing image of income inequality, even decades after it inspired Lyndon B Johnson to begin his war on poverty (Series: Caught In Poverty).
docs.snippet: A boom has helped produce fortunes for some in Texas, but poverty endures in shantytowns without basic services like water and sewers.

byline.original: By MANNY FERNANDEZ and CLIFFORD KRAUSS

docs.lead_paragraph: The plan opened the door to greater use of telemedicine and could alleviate the doctor shortage, a growing problem as millions of people gain insurance coverage under the Affordable Care Act.

headline.main: Medical Boards Draft Plan to Ease Path to Out-of-State and Online Treatment
headline.print_headline: Medical Boards Draft Plan to Ease Path to Out-of-State and Online Treatment

docs.abstract: Officials representing state medical boards across United States have drafted model law that could make it much easier for doctors licensed in one state to treat patients in other states, whether in person, by videoconference or online; opens door to using technology to alleviate doctor shortage, which has become growing problem as millions gain insurance coverage under Affordable Care Act.
docs.snippet: The plan opened the door to greater use of telemedicine and could alleviate the doctor shortage, a growing problem as millions of people gain insurance coverage under the Affordable Care Act.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

docs.lead_paragraph: International students are flocking to Kyoto, Japan's ancient capital, with 7,017 enrolling in the city's universities last year compared with 5,157 in 2009.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. Tull’s diagnosis of bubonic plague during a visit from New Mexico caused alarm in New York, where the disease had not been seen in more than 100 years.

headline.main: John Tull, Lawyer Whose Illness Created a Bioterrorism Scare, Dies at 65
headline.print_headline: John Tull, 65; Had a Rare Illness That Fueled a Bioterrorism Scare

docs.abstract: John Tull, New Mexcio lawyer found to have bubonic plague during visit to New York in 2002, sparking bioterrorism scare, dies at age 65.
docs.snippet: Mr. Tull’s diagnosis of bubonic plague during a visit from New Mexico caused alarm in New York, where the disease had not been seen in more than 100 years.
